uRER3SoGVkyaAohpbQmq4w.text: UPDATE: owner reached out to me directly to inquire about my yelp review however, they had the audacity to tell me they checked their security camera and didn't "see me there" and asked me if i could let them know when I came in. SO UNPROFESSIONAL. anyways, i did restate when i was there and what i ordered per their request. didn't even bother to respond to my reply and it's been over a week. poor service matches the quality of the food.   definitely a disappointment, literally came here ready to eat decent dim sum at 5:00 AM. prices were pretty affordable however, when it came to the food it was basically edible food poisoning. The seafood in all the dishes we had made both me and my boyfriend's stomach curdle with its overpowering fishy taste (a sign of old seafood) the pork and chive dumpling had such a terrible mushy texture i couldn't even swallow. even the tea had a soapy taste but i tried to drink it anyways. also didn't even get water when we were served but we saw everyone else got some. I was very disappointed because the servers were very kind and it seemed promising however, will not be returning to avoid a sour stomach.

YOt0M7v8JwwTV5i1M-hjpw.text: My family and myself LOVE this place for dim sum!   I have to say it is some of the best egg custard tarts I have ever had! Also, those are the first things I order.. ALWAYS. The wontons, shumai (pork dumpling), and congee come in a close second. I don't think there is anything here I don't like besides personal preference. I also like their salt and pepper pork chops which you do have to order through the kitchen, are to die for!  The hargow (shrimp dumpling) tends to always break and that would be my only "complaint" if there's one to be had.   If you ever need help guiding yourself through a proper dim sum experience, just call me. I will DEFINITELY make the time for all the foods!

xpElIK26YoVeGZrh4FD5KQ.text: Craving for authentic dim sum ?  This is the best place to have authentic dim sum in Vegas.  The food is delicious and the prices are reasonable.   Arrive before 9.30 am to avoid the crowds and be able to  find a parking spot on weekends.

qnR_MpDpN0JXLXBC3COWAw.text: Dim sum was great. Prices is excellent. I came in early and there is no waiting line. Serving on the cart and also available for order. Definitely is a great place to drop in for dim sum

pAPooy7F_3s4dGF70YoaUw.text: A hidden gem and an underrated Chinese restaurant!   We had dinner to celebrate my friend's accomplishments and the service and food were great! It was not busy (no wait at the time we went, 8pm weekday), service was attentive and fast. Our food came out faster than expected for a table of 10+.   For our starters, we had hot sake, tea and egg drop soup. haha Excellent way to start, especially on a cold winter night!   The dishes were huge and satisfied us. We definitely had leftovers for later.   My favorites were the walnut shrimp and crispy noodle.  I want to try their dim sum on my next visit.   TIP: In the same plaza as Mr Z Tea.  2018 Yelp Challenge Review #2

A0qgzzWJ3NaGHhRi2WdquA.text: Best dim sum in Vegas! Love this place since I was young and still loving it now. I love the environment here and food is delicious!  The only place that had sweet tofu for desert and pudding with milk as well!

i6Skfxs_LuypyvcZR0koPw.text: Hands down the best dim sum in Vegas and I've tried them all! Open late night, inexpensive and tastes like SF Chinatown that I grew up with.  After a night of drinking, we will most likely end it here. You know you know it's good? Mostly all Asians here! Lol

qfo5AseKgUHJiDt7x420Tg.text: Was craving dim sum during our Vegas trip so checked out Hong Kong Garden near the strip.  The number of carts wheeled around were plenty, offering a good assortment of dim sum goodness.  Congee hit the spot.  Siomai, Chinese broccoli, pork buns...can't go wrong with the basics.  Had to flag someone down to order yang chow fried rice separately.  If you're looking for smiles and courteous service, this won't be the place for you.  I had to go to the front counter to pay our bill.  Don't forget to check into yelp for your 5% off.  If you can look past having to yell "excuse me" a few times and just feel like some good chinese food, this place is worth your while.

sM-CRYc0a9G-Poya0NBD0w.text: Come here after 9pm for happy hour. Yes, HAPPY HOUR! At a Chinese restaurant. It's the first I've heard and been to. Prices are half off compared to their original price. They have a separate menu for happy hour (the smaller menu).  So far my favorite items to eat here is string beans in xoxo sauce, hot pot eggplants and salt and pepper pork chops. They also serve you complimentary soup at the beginning and the soup is also very good.

kVxpGDxzzAIX1dP7T93Iag.text: Food was good, waitress don't even care about your presence. Some of the waiters can't speak Cantonese but still take my order and ended up wrong foods.... when you ask for something they don't even respond to you, you need to ask again and again. Not like last time I was there for dinner, waiters more friendly and professional and speak English and Cantoneses. That's why I came back this time, sorry that I have to say but if the owner really sees my review I would suggest him or her to look into this problem and try to fix it before they lose more customer for bad service.

ZGd47GryPwyw1vE3pweISw.text: Pretty good dim sum, very reasonable prices and above average service (by Chinese restaurant standards at least) makes this restaurant a great choice off the Strip.  The dim sum is $2.29 (S), $3.19 (M) and $3.39 (L).  They roll out the dim sum in carts, they come by and show you what is available.  Don't worry if you can't speak Cantonese, you just need to point to what you what.  For folks who are not familiar with dim sum, I suggest trying the steamed shrimp balls (har gau ) and beef balls ().  Avoid the chicken feet, could be too exotic for most folks.  The dry beef chow fun () for $7.95 has a great wok flavor, not too greasy, and a generous portion.  This like many of their other dishes are great values, it's hard to beat the quality and price.  This is my favorite dim sum restaurant in Vegas by far, would highly recommend.  There is a Yelp check in discount.

Qp_xYWTQwKorzytjWhKN6g.text: The wife and I were in the mood for Asian fare this evening, but we couldn't decide where. So we said we'd drive up to Koreatown and go east towards Chinatown until something looked good. That's when we stopped at Hong Kong Garden.  Located on Spring Mountain Road, it's no more than 15 minutes from The Strip. When I tell you that we were well taken care of, that's an understatement.  For our appetizer, we enjoyed the spring rolls (very light!) and the soft shell crab. The crab was some of the very best I've ever experienced.  Then we had a very light vegetable soup, followed by scrambled eggs and prawns, along with sweet and sour whitefish. The eggs were very fluffy and seasoned to perfection, and the fish was expertly fried with just enough sauce to coat it, yet not too heavy.  For dessert we were brought a sweet red bean and tapioca soup. Looking at it you wouldn't think it would work...but it did! It was not too sweet, but sweet enough.  Generous portions and a relaxing atmosphere, it's worth driving across town or catching a rideshare from The Strip to enjoy! Needless to say, but we'll definitely return soon!

fID0pwmp-aAKs1ULO2qpqA.text: If you land in Vegas and want to enjoy some authentic, delicious Dim Sum, look no farther.  As a Chinese/American who frequently eats at Dim Sum places in both China & America, I feel like I've been developing the ability to locate solid Dim Sum places.   The atmosphere feels very authentic. Everyone, when we went, were Chinese people and the workers were Chinese as well. And the food tasted super authentic as well.  My standard for comparing Dim Sum places is usually comparing their chicken feet dish, since it's my favorite. Now, I don't say this lightly, but this was the best chicken feet I've ever had, in both America and China. Yes, I know, a crazy statement that defies the logic of "its so much better in China" which is usually totally True.  The chicken feet is meaty, a bit spicy, and served hot.   So, in short, if you wanna enjoy some Dim Sum before hitting the casinos, come here. It'll be the least risky gamble you make in Vegas.

Q2ZpDh0VOpmObreGNivClg.text: This place was smack crackle popping great dude. Like honestly 5 stars, 2 thumbs up, 10/10 gold rating would...no WILL COME BACK. IT WAS JUST THAT GOOD. The buns is a must, that egg tart more like egg heaven, and everything is just that good. Service is great too and they're so nice and friendly. If you're not already here eating while reading this review then you better put your phone down, drive over here and munch your heart away. Good vibes go there now :D  PS: it's open from 9am to 6am so those late night munchies heck yeah!

sFS7pufrsFBs_y1M2a9FSg.text: Our last meal in Las Vegas was dim sum, shared with Jean C.  She is such a fun, energetic person!  I was so happy for my friends to meet each other!  We selected this restaurant because it opened at 9am and we had to get to the airport by 11am... It's good to be early because we had our choice of free parking stalls! There was no line, so we were seated right away!   The steaming carts rolled past us and we chose all of the regular items: shrimp dumplings, siu mai, chicken feet, mochi rice wrapped in Lotus leaf, Chinese broccoli, jin dui, and char siu bao.  We asked for noodles, but there was no cook onsite, so we settled for jook (congee).    The Hom sui gok and Don tot took a while longer to come out of the kitchen.  The outer layer of the fried hom sui gok was on the thicker side - shucks. The middle of the don tat was mushy, but the crust had flakey layers of crispness!  Yum!  This is a typical dim sum restaurant with an adequate restroom and "normal" service. If you have limited time, this might be a good choice since it's quick. I still need to go to KJ's at the Rio...to compare...

BHf3f08Qo8E_oRe7HyvW6w.text: This has now become my go to spot to satisfy my dim sum craving. They open earlier than other dim sum restaurants which is nice.   They have all the typical dim sum dishes and a menu to order from. The service is pretty standard for a dim sum place. Quick but not the friendliest.   You can usually be in and out in about an hour depending on what time you arrive. Some carts seem to come around more often than others but that's to be expected.

9D8qxCujfdwjtsmDcjw-Kg.text: One of the best chinese restaurants i have tried here in Las Vegas. Want to know how you can call a Chinese restaurant an authentic one? Well it is if their locals eat from their restaurant. Its like their home away from home. Well I consider this as the restaurant close to my home. The good thing is they offer complimentary dessertand it satisfied my tastebuds!  For once I thought it is Champorado (chocolate soup with sticky rice) but it is made of red bean and sago pearls and they served it hot.

0ZVeMOMmXIZPj50XyEm9Yw.text: Subpar dim sum...and I'm comparing it to nyc sf n la dim sum. however it was pretty empty Sat morning around 1030 am so got seated quickly and not so hectic, was able to catch up with old friends. Staff were nice

eQFF26ETmrLsYIsKdWPwCQ.text: What a great place for some classic Chinatown style Chinese food. Their wine list is lacking but they make up for it with their food. Started with the pot stickers and the moo shu pork. Both excellent and highly recommended. We also had the sauteed fish, yang chow fried rice and shredded noodles. All tasty. The chicken with cashew was mediocre so I won't order it again. Four people with drinks came out to 75. Def will return

LPlD_u0Akx_c0L-P_RBQOQ.text: Coming to Las Vegas at least once a year for half my life, I had always been disappointed by the quality of Chinese food here - especially dim sum. With this last trip, I was craving some onolicious dim sum...BADLY.  Hong Kong Garden Seafood answered the call.  The service is fast and they're very attentive to when the plates begin to look too clean.  We had the char siu bao, mochi rice in lotus leaf, fried taro dumplings, shrimp siu-mai, shrimp/chive dumpling, tofu skin roll, chicken feet (mmmm) and shrimp har-gau.  Needless to say that the 3 of us were stuffed...  Conveniently located right on Spring Mountain Road, there's lots of parking, a clean dining area and did I say excellent service?  This is not a high-end sort of restaurant, so the prices are very reasonable.  If you want to satiate your craving for some solid, traditional dim sum, I recommend Hong Kong Garden Seafood & Dim Sum...

qSkmiwOGUtXYBxJHjcM1hw.text: Food is excellent, price is awesome, especially late night special. All new kareoke system with newest Chinese song, me and my friends loved it. I will definitely come back again !!!!

sPCwAcI5PfM4c-1W92W48g.text: Good luck finding a parking space. We come on a weekday and could find a parking space. Services suck big time. There four people at our table and we ask for 4 water and the lady brought two glass of water and slam it on the table. These are the waitress dress in black uniform, they just walk around doing nothing. Typical rude and uneducated Chinese. The ladies pushing the cart are nice. The foods are good to the bad services are really bad. Beware customer!! Don't expect friendly service. We never come back here again.

xB-5dIxUG4RLYPISLtX0aA.text: Let me see a show of hands...  How many here can speak chinese?  Well, for those that raised their hands, you'll probably think this place is OK.  For those like me that aren't able to speak chinese, there may be a chance that you'll have a tough time here and basically be ignored.  We got here right around lunch time on a Saturday and were seated quickly even though it was pretty packed.  First question from the young hostess was what kind of tea we'd like.  I asked her if they had black tea and she said she had no idea what black tea was...really?  She said they have oolong tea so that's what we ended up with.  First few minutes, the ladies rolling carts noticed we just arrived and had an empty table so the carts quickly came by and stopped to see if we were interested.  After about 4-5 cart visits, we had some pork shu mai, a char siu pork in sort of a pastry, some rice noodles with bbq beef, and some fishcake balls with chives in them.  These all were so-so, not good, not bad, but pretty much just OK.  I was really hoping for some xiao long bao and some char siu bao but no carts had any.  I asked one of the cart ladies if we could just order them but she said those would be coming around soon so we waited.   After about 10 minutes with the same carts with the same food going by we got the attention of one of the servers in black and tried to order them from her.  An attempt at a discussion went back and forth between us for a bit and it was finally revealed that she can't speak english so she gave up and walked away.  A few more minutes go by and all the same cart ladies with all the same food go back and forth by us and they know we're not interested in the food they have so they don't look our way.   Busboys scurry to and fro clearing plates and turning over tables.  Servers in black shuffle around the dining room bantering with diners lucky enough to speak the language. And we kind of just sat there feeling invisible for what was a good 20 minutes.  I see a guy who I think was the manager and ask for the check.  He notices we don't have too much to total up  and asks "is this all you guys are having?"  I answer back, "yep, we're definitely done here" and that was definitely the truth.  One thing to add, the table of four behind us was having the same problem as we were...difficulty communicating and no one coming by.  After a long time, one of them actually got up and chased down one of the speedy busboys that didn't already have his hands full so I know I'm not just being an overly picky diner.  I've had A LOT of dim sum in my time, some good and some not so good and sadly this place is at the bottom of the rung.  Dim sum that's just so-so but with some really bad service.

srgzZOpwsABTtw_-eW4CyA.text: It is very busy. We have 5 people, and can only order one Su-mai. Can you image? IT IS NOT ENOUGH. The food temperature is not controlled. We ordered one Clam with Oyster Source, and it is cold. Chicken feet is good. I know the waiter is trying her best, but the business is too busy that you can not get what you would like to have.

Hkxqps8q2HrW-kQ867NY-Q.text: Went xmas eve. 2 hours. No service. Half the food amd half the water arrive. Then nothing. Other tables waited longer with no food. Multiple tables walked out. Avoid.

yvUoemLrZdxtYsCRlFVh5g.text: I like this restaurant very much, the dishes in it all fit my taste very much, the waiter's attitude is very good, the environment is very clean, the food is fresh and delicious.

iEA-0Xj_rBAALSlU0-_2TA.text: Halibut was wonderful. Love the happy hour menu. Steamed gyoza -not great. Shrimp tempura - good but not typical. Do serve fresh wasabi !

9ScV9ldV6SZqC3q5yMdD7w.text: Good food , good price very bad service. Manager respond to previous review. We wil give it a shot.

UGbx8-qfJtE3iN6HVMC0nw.text: Las Vegas has multiple dim sum places that have popped up along Chinatown and Spring Valley. A few days ago, I was craving shrimp rice rolls and custard buns, and I decided to try a new dim sum place. Hong Kong Garden Seafood & Dim Sum Cafe was close to one of my favorite tea shops, so I decided to try it.   Hong Kong Garden was quite large and quite filled, so I knew that it was popular within the Chinese community. My friends and I were welcomed by the multitude of dim sum carts that frequently passed by our table. They had a large selection of dim sum choices, including shrimp rice rolls and custard buns. The service was fast, and the food was delightful. I recommend this place to anyone who wants to try a new dim sum place in Las Vegas.

qPvbxyezKeM8fw2dbSP3qg.text: I'm going to give them 5 stars for their egg tarts and roasted duck. The dim sum is okay. I've had better, but it's decent. Would come back.

9yo23GKrfa45UOLyD58AMg.text: Good is excellent. Restrooms are immaculate. We always go back for good food. Thanks for the friendly and prompt service. Dim sum the cart or off the menu. Absolutely delicious!! Lots of parking.

zjKSDboRcYFuKSv6x81v-Q.text: Off strip there's only 2 dim sum places on the west side that's any good.  Orchid garden and this place.  It's really a toss up as to which one offers the better food.  It's not the greatest dim sum in the world, but like I said, las vegas has two decent joints off strip.  The best dimsum is ping pang pong at the gold, and KJ at the rio.

dfGqNGxXhcmANtNCw-2gLA.text: We were seated right away. The service isn't that great. I don't know if there's a language barrier or what but our hostess barely said a word to us and most of the time pointed and nodded when communicating. The little ladies with the carts were pretty fast, they came around at least 10-15 times during our brunch. Their food dim sum is all right. The food came out kind of warm but by the time we were eating it it kind of went cold. I don't think I would go back because I have had better dim sum. The prices are reasonable bathrooms are clean and the food came out fast. It was meh.

GksaG0TpJUbjlDeC1ygYaA.text: We tried most of the dim sum here. I have been both early in the day, and just before 5. What is the difference? Same menu, and right before they stop serving dim sum (5 PM cutoff) you get it from the kitchen rather than from the carts. This is my go to place for Dim Sum. I was brought here by a friend who is Chinese and spends her time between both the Hunan province and Vegas. Worth visiting.

hQtZ5tffidj9uhElkEt1DA.text: Tasty dim sum for great price! For 3 adults our meal only came out to be $26 ! That's unbeatable price in Vegas. 15 mins drive from the strip

TRUcIcWxF9B8TV5z8kQg8w.text: I was looking for a dim sum place- cart style- to take my husband to for his first experience. Our Uber driver recommended this place and we were not disappointed. Genuine Cantonese dim sum that was fresh, hot, tasty. Only suggestion I would make is the more people you go with, the better, so you can try more things! Both of us were stuffed and had leftovers to go for around $30, so not ridiculous in price, either! My husband asked me to bookmark this place for our next Vegas trip, so good time had by all. I read they only do the carts until 3 pm so may want to check if you're planning on dinner.

xQPjeZmlSlsi3r14yn2vrA.text: Just find more and more tasty delights at this place.  Solid Chinese food that is well prepared and reasonably priced.   They start you off with a flavorful vegetable soup with a great broth.  The dishes come out hot and delicious.

SBUmbqSYzLuitFj2PBjk1w.text: I've come here a total of three times and each time gets worse and worse. I was here on a Saturday afternoon around 1pm. It was super busy. There wasn't a very long wait, which I was surprised at first. However, after realizing how closely they pack all the tables together I wasn't surprised anymore. We got seated in the dining area to the right of the restaurant. I was really disgusted at how unsanitary the bathroom was. There were two stalls and I took the smaller one of the two. There was a small trash can next to the toilet that was overflowing with toilet paper and tissues. I went to wash my hands and one of the women who worked there came out after me and finished washing her hands before me- it makes me question if she even used soap. Then, to top it off, they had no paper towels.   The food was alright. It's your typical dishes and nothing special. The lady pushing around the cart with the fried shrimp came back to give me a fresh batch, which was nice. Service wasn't spectacular. I asked one lady for a fork and a couple of sodas, and she didn't quite understand me and went to grab another lady. Apparently I was tending to my son and my back was to her, so I had to wave her down again.   The price is a little cheaper than other places, but you're paying for quality. I'd rather pay a little more for a better quality restaurant.

FUVFj94LIQIeDBAkNe7P2w.text: Good Cantonese food. Good dim sum. Reasonable prices. Don't get the fried oyster. But everything else is good.

_7WJiopXrQSsvu0QBFGufw.text: Been here twice. The food is good but the service is terrible. Both times they have forgotten to bring us dishes we have ordered. Both time we had to wait about 15-20 min to get each dish. Never again!!!!

jhe4kFh6KBEC6TzfiyO0jg.text: One spot that everyone should stop by and try.  Most Asian restaurants in vegas aren't that great. Therefore,  I recommended trying dimsum here .

3Vx195r3FuGBmbpuzJ4m7Q.text: First time for us coming here. There is ample of parking. Service is good and fast. Food was very flavorful and came in big portion.

b4sXt-YZSxrqumu3D8jYRg.text: Dim sum all day. Every time I'm in Vegas I make it a point to go. Great dim sum and decently priced. Far off the strip so itd nice to be away from those crowds although, they can get busy depending certain times. Good food all around.

ZqgcR-I6CRMGyXQrjPecAA.text: Best Dim Sum, a surprising find in Las Vegas.

PDyom2VGFssMAhc8OeqrFA.text: Dim sum gets a three stars, dinner were just acceptable, however their services were very good. Thus we only come here for dim sum only.

sBQlBngT3r3hkbbNFPlPlQ.text: It's good. Foods I would give 4 stars.  Very reasonable price and good portion.  I would definitely go back when in las Vegas.  The best hunan( steam chicken)chicken I ever had.  Dim sum reasonable price.

xOaPXe7tZTy7OL59Frf72w.text: The price of Dim Sum has gone up so much recently so I have not had the need to eat Dim Sum. For the amount and type of food, going with a larger family can really add up!   This used to be Cathay House, it's now Hong King Garden so we decided to try. Got a large table immediately, as the hostess sat us she was arguing with a co-worker! They were literally standing where I sat and yelled at each other.   We got our food before your drinks, terrible service which is typical of most Dim Sum places. Serve the same type of food, nothing unique from other places. I did not pay so can't tell you if it is cheaper or more expensive than other places.   Food was decent, not disappointing but not impressed either. Service was terrible, I did not expect great service but at least don't be yelling at each other while seating the guests!!

2fkug_-nmh64mKE7mjSz_g.text: Came here for dim sum this morning around 9. It was somewhat busy. Service was friendly and quick. The food served was warm. Even though they were small in size, the crust was flaky soft and the egg part was delicious.   Environment was kinda crowded, most of the tables and chairs were close to each other, but I liked how there's a big window view of pine trees, it's calming.   Overall, I recommend this dim sum place and their yummy egg tarts.

bUQh4U64JDbS6-udkLqICg.text: We really enjoyed this place. Dimsum was very good especially the shrimp and pork dumplings which are very hard to find and service was fast. Trust me, we tried. We will definitely go back here again if ever we are in Las Vegas. Highly recommended!!!

OBJdxqMuLlFb-X3ADyV1Ww.text: Dim sum done right! Been here a few times now and today we ordered dim sum to go. Uber easy, just checked the menu online and then called to place the order. They answered in Chinese but spoke English just fine. They said give them 15 minutes to prepare the order. Pricing is good here with small orders $2.29 each, medium $3.19 and large $3.99. Special items $4.99 and chefs specials $6.99.   Crazy the hours at this place, they open at 9AM and close at 6AM!   We ordered the steamed chicken feet with black bean sauce 5/5, shrimp, pork and veggie in bean curd sheets 5/5, baked coconut bun 5/5, steamed custard bun 4/5, fried sesame ball 4/5, fried shrimp and pork wonton 5/5, rice noodle roll with shrimp 5/5, shrimp har gow 5/5, steam pork dumpling 4/5. Great meal had by all and delicious to the last morsel!

cGj8tf6olrHEydLOjZq3cw.text: We came here because of a dim sum craving awe got to our favorite spot l, ping pang pong, too late to get dim sum. What a terrible mistake coming to this place was. Now for those new to Las Vegas, this is the old Cathay House, home to the best dim sum in Vegas for probably around 20 years.   The dim sum here is below average at best. Sugar cane shrimp was super greasy smelling of old oil, siu mai had a freezer taste to it, the fun noodles are supposed to be super slippery and tender, but these had a store bought thickness or toughness to it. The chicken feet were decent though.   We were totally dissatisfied with the dim sum, but we weren't full yet so we decided to order off the menu. The snow pea leaves we're actually very good, so we thought to try the geoduck sashimi soup combo. They brought out a dead looking 5 pound geoduck at $55 a pound... So I got up to inspect the live tanks and man oh man.. all the seafood looked dead, not a single thing was moving(see the video) So we immediately cancelled that order. Then we ordered a braised bird's nest soup at $31 a bowl, which isn't a bad price... But when there are no traces of the bird nest strings in the soup and they just tried to mask it by mixing in a ton of corn starch to thicken the soup so you can't tell, I'm gonna be upset.  The service here is bad. "Thank you's" were not met with "you're welcome's". Napkin requests were not acknowledged, they kinda just showed back up a few minutes later and slammed them on the table. It was bad.   From the lackluster food to the abysmal service, this was without a doubt, one of the worst experiences I've had in this city.

Nsq_d5zXgLb4J34jWtrGnw.text: Thank you for saving our lives! Well OK, not that extreme, but our visit to Vegas was past the mid-night point and waiting at a casino bar hoping to get served right away was getting impossible. So we looked up the nearest Chinese restaurant by us that's still open and ever so grateful for Yelp, we found this one!  My carnivorous friends and vegetarian bestie both raved the dishes they had (pork belly and buddha's delight, respectively). While I quietly but quickly devoured my Conch with Yellow Chives. Oh, Yellow Chives, they were so tender and fragrant, really elevate any seafood dishes! The only setback was the Conch was a bit too chewy, almost like dried, preserved seafood kind of texture...  There were quite a few tables of non-gambling ('cause why else would they be here this time of day!) Chinese just eating, shooting the breeze and having a good time. Made it really feel like an authentic Chinese restaurant. Did I say I appreciated their hours of operation? Yeah, I think they stay open for 20 hours of the day!

lrP0FIVZMzop4hgV2mOVMA.text: Prologue: It was lunch time on a Monday and my fiancee and I were in the mood for some good Chinese food to satisfy our craving. A previous online search of restaurants in the vicinity of Chinatown yielded this result along with several good reviews.  The Plot: This restaurant offers dim sum every day and it had been awhile since we'd had dim sum so we decided to do that. Our selections included a good assortment of traditional steamed items as well as pastry.  The Scene: We felt reassured about our decision to try this restaurant when, upon arrival, we discovered that nearly one hundred percent of the patrons were Asian, most of whom were probably locals.  All of our selections were as good as they should be to satisfy any fan of dim sum.  The highlights for us were the Braised Beef Tendon, which just melted in my mouth, and the Pork Ribs, which were extra meaty and steamed with a few small pieces of pumpkin that enhanced the flavor wonderfully.  The Egg Yolk Buns were soft, warm, with melted yellow custard inside, and were also very yummy. My fiancee requested two extra orders to take home.  The Rest of the Story: Our only minor disappointment was that the dim sum menu did not include any items that were different or unique. However, we were there on a Monday and it is likely that their weekend menu has more variety.  The service was prompt, not too pushy, and the prices were average.  Epilogue: I expect we will return on one of our future trips to Las Vegas so we can try their dim sum on a weekend.  Photo Design By: Billie Z.

ibi-UQqXIH-Cqo_mB0eafw.text: I was surprised when a friend suggested we go grab some dim sum in Las Vegas. You don't really associate those two things together but hey, I can always make room for Dim Sum.  The dining area is not as big as the dim sum places I'm used to in the 626 area but it was still pretty crowded at Hong Kong Garden. The pros (or maybe cons) of having a small dining space is that the dim sum carts gets to you a lot faster. I wasn't used to the dim sum cart speed over here but we managed to get what we needed in the first 10 minutes of dining.   The staff was nice and was on top of everything, but the dim sum here is just average. It's nothing special, but it wasn't bad. It'll satisfy your dim sum craving but that's it. I don't know if there is any other dim sum spots in Vegas, but if there isn't any, this spot would do just fine.

JvNQTirJAB7QKWv_ANaOog.text: If I could rate a negative star, I would. I didn't even get to try the food. Instead of being served, my mother and I sat there for 20 minutes, aside from being given water and tea, no one even bothered to check on us or even take our order. After that long of a wait, we left there hungry. Even as we walked out, no one even addressed us at all. The food here could be the best in town, but i very much wouldn't know, nor will i ever, because I will never return here.

KQBvKHIPVqWmV9VbapMR5A.text: One of the best dim sum places in Las Vegas. Has been my go-to spot on Spring Mountain Road for years. It's such a great place that offers authentic Chinese food. Wide selection of hot and fresh dim sum, desserts brought around the room on carts. Absolutely delicious and tasty!!! The price is reasonable compare to other dim sum restaurants in town. Weekends usually get pretty busy but the wait is never too long. The only problem is hard to get the server around the table. They tend to forget easily after they talk to me or mostly it takes a while for them to get back to my table. I totally understand how busy they are but it would be nice if they could pay more attention to their customers. Anyway...it doesn't really bother me at all because their food is always amazing, never get disappointed when I eat there. Definitely recommend it!!!!!

G7k6cOsMbYaMt8czXaNMSg.text: My favorite dim sum place in Vegas, thus far. I came here back in the early 2000's. It looked a little different and I still remember this old couple arguing about the lobster being a male or a female. I also spilled hot tea all over my lap.  If you don't know what dim sum is, think of it kind of like tapas. Small portions with the intent to share and have a variety to create your own meal. Have (and spend) as much or as little as you want. Order the same thing 4 times if you wish. But the variety is what makes it a thing of beauty.   It's affordable without sacrificing quality or quantity. It's comfortable even though it's a pretty large space with two separate rooms. I've come for dinner and for lunch. It seems like both rooms are only open for lunch and the dim sum carts. Dinner service is in the main room with no carts. I'm not super well versed in etiquette so I don't know if this is expected, but I thought it worth mentioning because I was still expecting the carts at dinner and all we received were separate menus.   The carts are filled with such a lovely variety of dishes! Congee, bao, shaomai, lotus leaf wraps, veggies, desserts of all different kinds. You can also place orders for different BBQ pork, duck and other kitchen items. A few of my favorites are the lotus leaf wraps, the shaomai, duck and egg tarts. I have never had a more delicious egg tart. It's so flaky! The custard is a sweet, creamy consistency. It's perfect. I love the egg tart here more than anywhere else in Vegas.  I prefer to go at lunch time because I feel that the carts are more convenient. I love that tea is served in pots instead of by the cup. It's so busy at all times of operating hours, which I like, because I don't feel like I'm being gawked at. That being said, service is still attentive.   Parking can be a bit of a pain because this plaza is poppin' so don't get discouraged if you can't immediately find a spot.

CA-HpOJFBTHnEG_334MLgw.text: Don't come here not worth it . Waited over 20 minutes not to be served . Walked out super disappointed. Waitress served and took other tables orders and walked passed us . We came in a party of 4 , but only received two menus and no water .  Spring mountain has A lot other restaurants and competitions and this restaurant is not worth it at all . I most definitely should of read the other posted reviews about the horrible service other people received. I been here before and Service most definitely went down hill . I will not return or recommend this restaurant to anyone .

-yfola5ViTOyAMXXAR1_jA.text: They Have Carts!!! Our usual place back home (Fremont, CA) we order and they bring you the dim sum dishes, so we were so happy that we found a place in Vegas with carts.  I love that!!!  They have all our usual favorites and even had my very favorite cocktail buns!  We came twice in the week we spent in Vegas.  So happy to find a dim sum place here.  Can't wait to be back.

xPX8G_2-AtDzbnJdO6eXAg.text: This is one of my aunt's favorite places in Vegas to grab dim sum, and when compared to the other local dim sum joints in the area, I can see why. This place is open from 9 AM to 6 AM - almost 24 hours, and the restaurant is pretty big. It does get busy on weekends, but with people coming and going so often, you won't have to wait too long.   They still have the traditional cart wheeling dim sum, which I appreciate. I've never seen them run out of items, and if they don't have a specific item just yet, they'll be able to get it for you in a few minutes.   The standard dim sum items have always been pretty good - radish cakes, chicken feet, siu mai, etc. I don't think they have the egg yolk buns here, which is a little disappointing; however, their egg tarts are pretty delicious - flaky crust and very ooey and soft center.   I've also been able to try some of their other dishes like the Singapore style noodle, broken rice soup, etc. All have been really tasty and at a pretty affordable price.   The interior of the place isn't the newest or cleanest, but you're basically getting an above average dim sum meal in Las Vegas. I would have to say that the dim sum here does not compare to the SGV area, but you make do with what you have.   Workers are friendly and will help you whenever you let them know you need something. They offer a Yelp check-in, which is pretty nice. Parking lot can get crowded as it's in a busy plaza, but so far we haven't had trouble parking.   tl;dr - Above average dim sum at an affordable price. Hours are very good and service is above average.

TOZUehYGZmQL5LYWjVm3-A.text: I have been coming here for years now. However, a few recent visits have shown me that this place has changed, and it's unfortunate that they have not changed for the better. The taste of their dim sum has gone down. The service is not that great, the prices are okay, and the variety is what you would expect at any other dim sum place.

0yMLIFtdSQKWWYMfraxwtw.text: Food is so-so, service is terrible.... Doesn't seem like anyone clean the bathroom since yesterday and it smells like hell Waiters have no clue about the menu and lot of items were missing. Not going to recommend to anyone

S4B_i22SR08X_wOenAlHmw.text: I've never been to other dim sum places in Las Vegas Chinatown...so I can only compare to what I've eaten before.   I came here with a party of 7 on a Wednesday afternoon at 12:15 pm. I had called earlier to make sure they still served dim sum and they also took my reservation!   We came at 12:15 pm and they were in a scurry to clean our table and seat is. Okay, that's fine. But the whole point of "" is to drink tea along with your food! We didn't get any service for tea 20 minutes into dining even though the cart ladies were already bombarding us with options.   We ordered quite a bit!  -Fung Zhao (chicken feet) // classic dish. Pretty sweet, not spicy enough. But not bad for what they had!   -Har gau (steamed shrimp dumpling) // Okay, this was butchered. Not so crystal skin and it was cold and falling apart.   -Siu Mai (open topped steamed pork or shrimp dumplings) // a bit too oily for the pork! But still yummy. *Be warned, we found a piece of hair in this. Luckily we could exchange it...*  -Jiu Cai Bau (fried wheat starch skin dumpling with chives) // yum! I would get again. It was a bit on the oily side but stuffed with good amount of meat and thin skin.   -Cha Siu Bao (steamed BBQ pork stuffed buns) // Mehhh. I'm not a huge fan of this item regardless of where I get it.   -Cheong Fan (rolled rice noodles) // errrr. Probably one of the worst I've had. Not big and soft like other places! This was tiny and stale....too much soy sauce added and really cold! The beef one was gross, shrimp was doable. Luckily we didn't order too many!   -Pei Guen (steamed tofu skin roll) // Classic dish that I love! They did okay with this- you seriously can screw up steaming this. But the only complaint I have is that the stuffing inside was way too little and did not have the classic bamboo shoots.   -Lo Mai Gai (steamed glutinous rice) // Not flavorful at all, and barely half a teaspoon of stuffing in the center. Regret!   -Daan taat (egg custard tart) // This was a disappointment (like everything else). But I guess it's good for the kiddos!   -bowl of intestine soup // too sweet, but I love intestines regardless.   -bowl of pig blood soup // not a super clean taste- can still taste some of the "freshness". Good portion though!   -plate of stir fried beef and rice noodles // Good! Pretty decent potion, not too oily and enough beef for everyone.   Pros:  -Helpful service. They were patient and helpful with out questions and needs.  -cheap? I would say for 8 people, we only paid $85 before tax.   Cons:  -Not a lot of options rolling around. And I mean, literally, rolling around. The classic Cheong fan wasn't being served unless you requested it!  -No menus. It's nearing lunch time and I would think that you'd give us a lung menu too since the cart ladies were taking off! You'd have to be a frequent here to be able to understand what they are doing...  Tips/Observations:  -parking lot is small! Be prepared to circle around.   Overall, never again....I would check out other places besides here.

5LMxrwvOcCzR1dF29EppTw.text: The worst Chinese food I have had so far in Vegas. Overpriced and the portion of food way too small. zBRxMwrY9u73OTjm4z6coA.text: I've been going here since the old owners and the the food is still great! I ordered my go to Shrimp/Pork Shumai, Salt n Pepper Pork Chops, & Chicken Pan-Fried Noodles. Everything was great!   However, The restaurant is so unsanitary. Especially the restrooms. I saw toilet tissue all over the floor, mold on the sink, no paper towels, hand soap stains in the sink. It was filthy! Before looking at the bathroom, I felt a little iffy so I didn't even want to drink out of their cups and wanted to buy a fresh bottle of water instead. I hope the new owners know that this could ruin their business reputation. I don't know about you but I like to eat in a spotless clean, sanitary restaurant.. I really do enjoy eating here, but I just don't think I can handle knowing the restaurant's employees are filthy and dirty :(

B66rBfasN1by2ZWs3DimxA.text: Extremely disappointed with this dim sum location. I decided to come here on Christmas with the family and grab a good brunch before heading out to holiday festivities.  Once walking through the doors I smelled the wreaking of a wet mop slapping me in the face. Very sour and pungent smell and lurks around. Everything else around wasn't opened till later so I still decided to sit down and eat. The tea we ordered wasn't even hot, Luke warm at its best.  Once ordering a few dishes I was just making sure this dish I ordered was warm, the waitress comments back saying "then don't eat it if it isn't warm" this got me furious. Just a simple question making sure the dish I wanted was warm but she decided to be very rude. Probably won't be coming back here or suggesting a place like this to people I call friends or family.   The waitress also brings the food to the table and after setting it down she decides to wipe down her hands on the table cloth that we were eating at.

xDogbMLj01bnXgUXB5BgMA.text: The food is delicious and that's the only reason I'm giving them a three star review. Once upon a time, my husband and I used to love coming here. As usual I ordered the salt and pepper fried pork, salt and pepper calamari, seafood tofu soup and shrimp fried rice. The food was just absolutely delicious. Everything seasoned just right. Now the service was just horrible. I've given them a two star review before for the same reason. But back then I thought just maybe we should give them another try. When we did ended up coming back, the service had changed. Their customer service was back on point. But after our show tonight we decided we wanted some Chinese food and  decided on here.  The staff looked tired and agitated. No greeting, no smile. When we ordered our food, the waitress seemed unhappy. We had to ask a waitress twice for my husband's drink. It was an unpleasant experience. I don't think we'll be going back again.

wL1quCHXI7wUx4jIRL22KQ.text: I am a big fan of dim sum and I like to be here.  Taste, service and cleanliness are must, I think but as many think so, Chinese restaurants  look be missing at least one of them.   Our server put on gloves and collected bowls and plates with food garbage left on the table . And she brought our and other customers foods wearing the same blue disposable gloves.    OMG !   Touching food garbage and bringing new food .......  If they do not care of this kind of issues, many people do not come again.   I hope they read my complaint and realize how cleanliness is big-league operating a food business.

fmrj4eIbGLRWnM84CsqvIA.text: Pretty good dim sum with solid service! Although somewhat far from the strip (10-15 min drive), this restaurant in the corner of a somewhat newer plaza served a delicious Cantonese brunch at a reasonable price.  Highlights: shrimp noodle (not har gow- although the har gow was also good), very fresh, not too oily, and great texture, chinese broccoli, egg tarts (nice and crispy, bite size), xiao long bao had some soup   The waiters also took down orders quickly if we didn't see what we wanted on carts and brought out drinks quickly as well. This is a good alternative to brunch on the strip if you don't wanna throw down $$$.

photos.caption: Photo of Hong Kong Garden Seafood & Dim Sum Cafe - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Assorted Dim Sum

JWhrOMBpyRf5Jf59NXOf3Q.text: New Year's Eve dinner with the family, and to our surprise the Jones location was closed.  That's what we get for not checking 1st...  Luckily, the Spring Mountain location was open and we were happily surprised to see our favorite waitress there!  We started with the house soup and then went crazy from there!  The salt and pepper calamari is my favorite dish - nicely cooked and season - eat it while it's hot!  The Peking Duck is presented nicely on steamed buns and the rest of the duck is served on a platter.  Spare ribs, pan fried noodles, and broccoli oh yes!  The broccoli has a nice crunch to it and the black bean sauce on the ribs is outstanding, not too salty.  My Pops always orders the sweet and sour pork, and I have to give him props for actually trying the other dishes this time.  Way to go Pops!    The Tsing Tao and Sapporo is icy cold and served in chilled glasses.  Why only four stars?  The bathroom.  I can't wait for the new location to open because the bathroom was bad.  Yuck.  Back to the food!  The food is good!  Well cooked, well seasoned, and generous portions.  And that calamari... nom nom nom

P93bI_JwtwAkhDNk_M1r1g.text: One of the many dimsum places in Las Vegas. I've tried better. Their Chinese food is much better. Prices are fair and have good portions.

Ylqch2z8M4FM454gkLIrGA.text: Great efficient service. The carts keep coming. Everything from taro cake, to pork bun to traditional dim sum. I have had dim sum in every big city in America including NYC and SanFrancisco and this was just as good!

QOUSRPpbm2BWUUmw6ZODkg.text: I went here for dimsum. It was pretty authentic and delicious but not many dimsum menus.  If you are craving for Hong Kong food, I would recommend it!!

qUGuSEcyJXCa0BqC3WsWrg.text: I've been here numerous times and enjoyed the cheap food, but the last time I've been here was probably the worse time I've been here. I was sick so I wanted to enjoy some good comfort food I ordered the shrimp dumplings because those were some of my favorite my nose was stuffed and a small cough and I was dying for some food so I stuffed an entire dumpling in my mouth and swallowed the entire thing. I noticed a slight taste at the back of my mouth as I swallowed it. The shrimp was foul and now I was worried that I was going to get shellfish poisoning. When going to this place be wary of the food and don't scoff it down like I did. I luckily didn't get food poisoned and my body fought it off.

pIdfXx9LlRIZGVI3xQPUIQ.text: Walked in for the first time, and no one really knew English, the ladies with the carts started passing us food we didn't want and we never been there before so we had no idea. The food was good but it was sooo overpriced. It was just me and my husband and when we ended paying $70.00. What a rip off, no menu no nothing. Never again.

7Cwl06g5R90tLhcZhzvggA.text: A wonderful dim sum place!  We went New Years Day - excellent selection of dim sum and the employees were exceptional- super friendly and helpful. Thank you for helping us start the new year on a bright note!

vzUJw6bYqMA6XdjOZoYHzA.text: This is one of my favorite place. Dim sum is delicious. Only thing is you need communicate thouroughly wth them. we oder something in the menu got 2 order comes out.  Otherthan that food is good

AAkdlAhYZLCaR9Hhyf6BTw.text: AVOID THIS PLACE AT ALL COST!!  Made reservations for 13 for dinner and was seated in the private "VIP" room but everything about the meal here was far from that experience...  Waiters didn't know anything about the menu and dishes at this restaurant. My family asked about the fresh/live seafood selection but all questions went completely over their heads. The wait staff made zero effort to serve us other than dropping off the dishes. They even left a thermos of hot water for us to refill tea ourselves. When time came for the check, we had to go outside to flag down a waiter and bring the check/payment to the front desk. The hostess at the front desk didn't talk or even make eye contact when ringing me up; no "thank you" nada. We just spent more than $500 dollars on this terrible dinner with no service at all...  The service MIGHT be tolerable if the food was delicious BUT IT MOST CERTAINLY WAS NOT!! Either no salt/flavor or too heavy handed with some dishes. The quality of their "live" seafood is also unacceptable for the price in addition to the way they prepared the dishes completely ruined the sub-par fish quality. Some dishes were just thrown together with all the vegetables they found in the kitchen to mask their complete lack of understanding for that particular dish; just random pops of colored veggies to "brighten up" the dish, no cohesive taste or reason for the selections. Other dishes were completely forgotten, even when the waiters repeated our large order several times to us.   Save yourself the trip and eat something else, anything else in Vegas Chinatown. It will be probably be a better meal...

Y2Yrrm33TW7bZyV3zMbDTQ.text: DO NOT COME HERE. If you are debating to come to this restaurant, just stop. I came here after a long weekend in Vegas, Hungry and wanted some dim sum food. One of the waiters that was assisting us looked like she was on drugs. Waiters were all over the place and not watching tables like they should. You are better off eating Sushi in Vegas than eating here.   Service: bad  Food: horrible Cleanliness: bad

WHa7tcXMlRm7XlVByaRpMw.text: Another lacklustre though authentic dim sum joint. The egg custard here was good, everything else was unremarkable. Service is quite typical for a dim sum place, perhaps on the expedient side.

N6CIcmZiBYtneWmHFeT9og.text: Hong Kong Garden is clutch when you're in Vegas and want some authentic ish Cantonese food and are trying to avoid the Panda express or buffets.   We over partied and decided to stay in, so around 11 we were famished and saw that there was a china town near by. So needless to say we headed over. We saw that Hong Kong Garden had a wild verity of dim sum, soups, noodles and rice which was the perfect heavy hang over remedy.   It does a while for the waitresses to help you out but I guess you can use that time to go over the menu. I was dying for egg drop soup so we got an order that was def more than enough for two, we actually took a large container back with us because there was so much left over. We also ordered some Shrimp har gow, a few order and some sweet shrimp.  While we waited for everything to come out we were handed some yummy green tea to sip on. About half way into the first cup of tea the egg drop soup was dropped off. We dove it, it was good, eggy and just as it should taste. Again very soon after the shrimp har gow was dropped off. It was so delicious I loved it so much, I added some chili and soy sauce to make it a little spicy. YUM.   But the def go to for the night was the sweet shrimp. It is minced shrimp rolled into a ball and fried with a piece of sugar cane. It was so savory, sweet and crispy. I loved it!! Over all I was very happy with Hong Kong Garden, i know i will def be back when i visit Vegas.

6_cwiydIXhPhokmqD-0KBA.text: I came here for Dim Sum with family members Sunday morning at around 11:00 A.M PST. It's pretty easy to get to, towards Spring Mountain and Jones, about 10 minutes from the Strip.  The place was packed! The whole front entry had people standing inside and you could barely move around.  Our party, since it was relatively large, had the private room inside the restaurant. Because the private room is separate from the main restaurant, the carts do not come by the private room. You have to pre-order off of the menu.   The food came out quick and everything was hot. We had a variety of foods, Hong Kong Chow Mein, Jian Dui, Char Sui Bao, White Rice, Bok Choy, and Fried Tofu. I ended up just eating the Jian Dui, but my daughter loved the Bok Choy and the Hong Kong Chow Mein! We didn't receive much service outside of the initial plating of the food. Our party had to ask for waters, and when we finally received it, we waited about 10 minutes or so for the drinks to come out. During the Dim Sum, we never had any refills on the water. Service was sub-par.  The women's bathrooms when I came here on Sunday were atrocious. It was quite the experience.The trash was over-flowing in the stall. The toilets were dirty. The sinks were rusted and not properly working. It was very unsanitary.   Overall this is a decent Dim Sum place, but I won't be back here anytime soon. I'll check out some other Dim Sum places in Las Vegas.

rZPDgQmxnQRJi67K5lUKDg.text: This is by far my favorite dim sum place in Las Vegas. I have tried many other places but always come back to this one. The food, quality, and taste are consistent day in and day out. They have a lot of seating but can get crowded in the morning with a bit of a wait time (~ 30 mins). They push carts (until 3pm) filled with all sort of dishes that you can choose from. It's definitely an experience you must try. You can still order other non dim sum dishes as well. It's better to come as a large group so you can have more of a variety to eat but nothing wrong if it's just you and another person.

4Vpqsoic7auJy5x1xRkseg.text: Wanted Dim Sum when I was in town and I've tried a handful of the top ones listed on Yelp. So, Hong Kong was next on my list.   Only a few miles away from the strip which is a plus and lots of parking too. Clearly this is a popular restaurant because people kept coming in.   When you walk in someone will greet you and take you to a seat. Left side has a view with large windows and the right side is just regular looking dining room.  Push carts going by fast and keep in mind some do not speak English.  Great selections for Dim Sum.  Although service was fast, my shumai was cold.  I get it that they push the cart around and it can get cold but that was my only disappointment.  I still ate it.  Prices are reasonable and not overly priced.   I will definitely return and recommend this place.

UKgqM-Zh_J86XwCU5KyDqQ.text: If I could give this 0 stars, I would!! I used to be a fan of this place but food safety is so important and this restaurant seriously needs to be shut down! Please don't go here you guys!!   A party of 5 of us came around 1AM and were the only ones in the restaurant. There were 2 servers who were eating their meal at the table behind us and when 1 of them came to take our order, she was still chewing her food! We ordered wonton soup, chow fun, fried rice, and fried tofu. The food came out and this is when it went all bad...  Our wonton soup came out and my bf noticed 2 black bugs floating around in it. We told the server right away and she offered to make us a new one. Next came the chow fun and this one was the worst - there were little bugs all over it! We counted AT LEAST five and that's just on the surface! The server finally came back with the new wonton soup and when we told her there were bugs in our chow fun she rolled her eyes! THEN she continued to deny that they were bugs and said it came from the meat.. gross. She started getting extremely defensive and making excuses for why there are bugs in their food. The replacement wonton soup that came out ended up having more bugs floating in it as well. Imagine the bug infestation in that kitchen!!   We knew they were bugs because they had little legs and little wings. They didn't even apologize. In fact, they took the wonton soup and chow fun and put it on their table and ate it. If they want to eat bugs, cool!! But don't serve it to your customers. Smh. NEVER COMING BACK!

photos.caption: Photo of Hong Kong Garden Seafood & Dim Sum Cafe - Las Vegas, NV, United States. I didn&#39;t want to post this picture, but owner was denying that there were bugs... this is clearly a bug!

exK-t-0Yd9JAqyT_VKcZ0g.text: So here's the thing. The food was okay, but the main problem was my waitress.  For the past three weeks I have come to this restaurant and got the same waitress. She is the thin woman with a ponytail and wears all black.  A few weeks ago, I ordered chat leong, but the waitress brought over jasmine tea. Also, there were only two of us, but she gave us two tea pots. That was really weird.  The following Wednesday morning around 9:20 am, we got the same waitress again. I was with my father, and I had wanted to order chat leong, but I did not because of what happened last time. Chat Leong was my dad's favorite, but I was afraid the waitress would mess it up again.  I can only come on Wednesdays, and everytime I come to the restaurant I see that same waitress again. If you want me and my family to come back, GET RID OF THAT THIN WAITRESS. She does not know what she is doing. She never understands what I am asking! If you want to keep the waitress, then I will never come back.  I am tired of asking for a different waiter or waitress everytime I eat here.

_ouljahdqJRFBWZce9zWfw.text: We were on this side of town and had some time to kill, so what better way than to order some dim sum to go? Parking lot is tiny and it seems like nearly every space is labeled for which business you can park in, but we found a spot. Packed at 9:40 AM on a Wednesday.  It was pretty crowded inside and even while we were waiting, nearly 15 people came in. Their hours said 9AM to an adjusted 6AM so they must have steady business. I wish they had a menu that had pictures to make sure I got exactly what I wanted; just a title of the food without a description and a S M L next to it which seemed to coincide with a price. Ended up getting: hargow, shumai, shrimp rice noodle, Chinese sausage bun, fried potstickers, and an order of gailan (Chinese broccoli). Total came to about $25. We waited in the corner on some chairs surrounded by old stereo equipment and signs. We might as well have been put in a closet . It took about 15 minutes for our food to be ready; they placed it on the divider wall behind us and never said anything. At one point I noticed it and stood up and had to ask if that was ours. So customer service isn't the best but prices were reasonable; now let's look at flavor. I really enjoyed my dim sum from here. It was packed with flavor and still tasted fresh even after the 30 minute trek home. The rice noodle and gailan both came with sauces which was nice. I was very happy with the portion size of the gailan which was a large size to go box, rather than the smaller ones. All in all I would go back the next time I'm in the area!

ZJ71EPM1m_yqS5r54VXhrQ.text: Formerly known as the Cathay house, I've been coming to this restaurant for decades.  I'm glad the new owners still make this an easy place to get dim sum during the work week lunch and that's the standpoint I'll be reviewing from.  HK Service:  There's plenty of tables in the main dining room as well as the banquet room which they open up for additional seating when necessary.  The staff gets you seated immediately after you enter.  The Dim Sum carts are stocked well and the crew moves quickly hrough the restaurant.  If you were looking for something in particular, just wave one a cart down and they'd find the right cart to send over.  Classic old school Chinese restaurant decor is what you'll find here with a nice view of the Strip in the main dining room.  HK Dim Sum:  They have the classics and all the dishes I've had have been freshly made and pretty tasty overall.  Here are my "go to" for business lunch Dim Sum meetings: Pork Bun, Shumai, Shrimp Rice Noodle, Shrimp Dumplings, Chinese Broccoli (to feel healthy af), Crispy Shrimp (with sweet mayo) and noodles for the side.  Dessert orders:  The Sesame balls and the egg custard are my favorites.     Even during a weekday lunch rush, I'm able to get parties of 6+ seated immediately and the table full of yummy dim sum dishes quickly.  This is the main reason why I visit frequently when the topic of dim sum come up at work.  Enjoy! =)

l7S2Jory27yDGJY3Y79lkQ.text: It's good. Not over good of spectacular. It's just good. The roast pork was way too oily and fatty but everything else was good. We were the only ones in there so service was great! But the food was not good enough to want to come back again. The other location was AMAZING. Not sure what happened with this one as a sister location or a move?

EMZxgXaT7icuSkDgBEI-jg.text: Was craving dim sum for lunch so my mom and I decided to give this place a try. We came on a busy Friday afternoon so parking was very difficult to find.   Surprisingly, we had no wait and were seated right away. They're constantly pushing the carts around so you don't really have to wait long to order what you want.  My go to dim dum choices are: tripe, chicken feet, shrimp rice noodle, shrimp dumplings and shiu mai. I order at least two of each because they're SOOOO good.   Although the food was really good and service was great, I couldn't rate this place a full 5 stars because the shrimp dumplings were way overcooked because it was very dry. I couldn't even chew it because it felt like rubber. I had to throw away most of the shrimp dumplings because of that.   Overall, I really liked this place. Great atmosphere and the food was good (despite the shrimp dumpling issue) haha.

6MpT4m9ZEWqpwQ1fLm1BrQ.text: If your not Asian... they don't give a rats ass if you are there or not! Don't expect to be given a menu unless you hunt someone down and ask for one.  My nieces has a craving for Dim Sum and wanted to try this place out. Upon walking in you see a lot of server pushing carts with several food options. It's a little difficult when the server doesn't speak English very well and you can't really understand what that are offering .   My sister and I decided to order off the a menu, we kept asking the ladies who would push the carts if we could get menus and it felt like they were just brushing us off, like one lady would tell they other on in their language and then she would tell someone else and our request was just being bumped around.   We finally got our menus and ordered off them. Within 15 min, I got sick, I had to excuse myself to rush over to the ladies room and it all quickly came up! Luckily when I returned, most of our party had finished eating and I didn't have to wait long to leave.   I HIGHLY doubt that I will ever come back to this spot again. Luckily the rest of my family, said their food was okay, they would rate is as a 6 1/2 out of 10.

QPtrxPqkV6SMipVRx2QZmA.text: Really good dim sum in unpretentious surroundings..! Great bang for the buck! Great food for reasonable price.. I get my moneys worth and i am not paying for decor or ambience! Dim sum is good, cheap and not greasy!

photos.caption: Photo of Hong Kong Garden Seafood & Dim Sum Cafe - Las Vegas, NV, United States

glM_hQgDw8Fx9jisXyRxRA.text: YEEEEESSSS! I think we found ourselves a new dim sum place. ONLY downside is - the carts take a break lol.  If I'm not mistaken, the dim sum carts are available between 9am-3pm and then are not available until 9pm-3am (or was it 6am). Between the hours of 3pm-9pm, I am told that dim sum items are still available for order off the menu.  The carts are more fun in my opinion.  We used to frequent another establishment because we thought we finally narrowed it down to one of the best in last vegas. BUT, I think we stand corrected.   When we were here, we just felt like we were more welcomed. The people who worked there were so patient and kind to explain over and over what I didn't understand. And the ones we normally order from other places, we found had better quality here. Like the shrimp ball and shrimp har gow. I was really excited when I ordered the Chinese broccoli and they cut it in half! Made it easier for me to eat the stems and leave the tops for my hubs. The noodles on the dim sum tray was also a good size and was soft and delicious. Other places I've ordered it were crunchy. This was enjoyable and not greasy.  It seemed we were brought into a private room that was opened up to accommodate additional parties that had come to dine for lunch so I inquired about it with our server. The private room we were in could accommodate about 120 people. And when I inquired if they allow for reservations for smaller parties, he told me there were other rooms also available that can accommodate smaller parties as well. He was so kind as to show us. One room was small enough to accommodate 12-16. Another room could accommodate 36-40.   We got excited! It is definitely one we could consider if we have family in town.  On top of dim sum, they also have a full menu of Chinese food.  We will definitely be back for more!

wFiDXrPmbwAgFiwzQBuLaQ.text: Best dim sum ever! Very fresh ingredients and totally authentic (I grew up in Hong Kong). What surprised me the most was how friendly and attentive the service here. Not the norm in most Chinese restaurants. We will definitely come back!

3Axp2nNxPEieyzb7GN99-g.text: SUNDAY // DIM SUM  Sunday funday, family time. We arrived as soon as they opened.  We noticed there was a large crowd outside with all this loud chaos. What is going on?! It was the DRAGON DANCE performers to celebrate Chinese New Year!! How fun and festive.  We were seated right away. There's 2 separate dining area so there's plenty of seating. The restaurant filled up quickly. The dim sum carts were fresh and hot, ready to be served. They had a good variety of dishes to pick from. I would come back again.

8d3gOWj0-5nhFCQ6knrxBw.text: So glad they have a new location! The original spot burned so they are east of Jones on Spring Mountain.  Boyfriend and I visited the new spot on Saturday after 12midnight and had the discount menu. Most items were $5.95 to $10.95.  What a great deal for great food!! Super delicious!  Highly recommend the salt & pepper pork chops, Singapore rice noodles, fried fish... great food!!!

FHla-aQ-4gsm0ntV2TCjEA.text: I must say, there is a lot of potential here.  I love me some old school dim sum with the carts being pushed around by the ladies.    The decor, simple, fresh and clean without any clutter on the walls.  The cleanliness of the place including the tea pots (though mismatched) offers a sense of hope that my food will be wonderful.  The price point is just right, not too cheap and for pretty decent quality.  We didn't get charged for water or tea, so that was really cool.  I'm used to paying per person for tea in California.  If I had to nit-pick, the food is not covered. They walk around with the food completely exposed and the chances of the top ones getting cold by the time it reaches my table was pretty high. The likelihood of germs getting on them was pretty high too. It's a little cumbersome to lift all the covers, but it's all part of the cart process.  Am I the only one who got cold food even during peak lunch hour on a Monday?  That was a big factor for my 3 stars.   Har gow- the dough was ripping off exposing the shrimp, had a really doughy taste so we'll have to pass next time.  Not my favorite dish to order and that fact it wasn't good made it worse.  Siu mai- Just like what it should taste like, meaty and never salty.   Cheong fun- My husband enjoyed it, by the time I got to the last one, it was a folded too thick and the meat (never in abundance) was not quite the right ratio.  Char siu bao- The dough again for me wasn't on par.  It wasn't terrible, but the mixture of the red char siu is a mixture of sweet and salty and just ends my meal on a good note.  Chicken feet- oh yeah!! Not only it's considered a small dish price, it was delicious with the right amount of spice and the ooey gooey sauce that is lathered all over 4-5 pieces of this tender dish.  Bean curd vegetarian- Usually an awesome dish. A mixture of vegetables, water chestnuts and beautifully folded in bean curd. My lady gave me the top one and that is what left me with a sour note to my review.  I hate luke warm dim sum. Since I didn't have time to complain, I'll have to ask for a warmer batch next time.

KoTxjHvIw33WPLfiCge5RQ.text: Overall, it was an interesting experience. I was skeptical at first since there were a few fishy guys smoking in front of the restaurant, but they left as I entered anyways. My top dishes that I would eat again (and in fact, ate again) were the egg tarts(the second best egg tarts I've had), the broccoli, the shrimp hargow, and the tofu(without the sugar). I also enjoyed the experience of people pushing around carts and letting us choose what we wanted. The environment was a little crowded in my opinion. The reason I rate this restaurant a three is because those four dishes, out of EVERYTHING my friends and I ordered, were the only dishes I generally liked. Hope this helped!

xBIam6cworLY7-gM_jQH6g.text: Always good, love the tea. The Mongolian Beef is awesome. I love their shrimp fried rice, and sweet saki.  Our girl hideaway spot.

bWX5wG9gb8keOhZbUbxWxA.text: Cheap eats at its best! This unassuming restaurant off the main strip is in Chinatown and part of a little strip mall.  Don't let the hole-in-the-wall appearance fool you, the service is good and the food even better.  Prices were very reasonable with our party of 10 easily accommodated, portion sizes of all dishes were decent and our bill landing just shy of $100USD.  They treat you to a house soup to start, which is a "soup of the day" bone broth. Food came out hot and fresh and flavored well.  We had seafood dishes which included clams, scallops, shrimp all were fresh (the have live tanks displaying some fish and lobster as well).  After the meal, there was a dessert soup offered.   All in all if you're looking for a great meal out without breaking the bank in Vegas, this is a great choice!   *their hours of operation are great opening 9am to 6am daily; lots of parking;  ***lots of locals eating there**

R0ZzqtnpY2Y1NeuQz6TvQA.text: Been to this place so many times now and I'm so happy I finally got pictures of their food! I think this is one of the best places for dim sum compared to the other places I've tried here in Las Vegas.  The restaurant is nice and clean, staff are friendly but the ones that push the cart for the food are always in a rush.   My sibling and I got our regular food from dim sum and it was nice and warm, not cold like other places.   All in all, for sure I will be back to eat here as I've been eating here for about 5 or 6 times now! Delicious, fresh and there are many ladies pushing the cart around to get all your food!

Eue7OByK1oF89vN8aGMT0Q.text: Came here twice so far and LOVING this restaurant! When I first came to this restaurant during dinner time, there were MANY choices of food to choose from the menu. There was many different dishes from fish, fried rice, seafood, pork, chicken, and more.  The employees here are nice. There were some food that are especially good. It tasted like my other favorite Chinese restaurant. I would recommend coming to this restaurant because it's AFFORDABLE AND GOOD!

y19tvd688DqxDnmoBdJkOA.text: The 4 star is for the food NOT the service. The service was shitty but that's  expected at a place like this. We went on Sunday during brunch time and was able to get a table for 10 very quickly.   We hard such a hard time order non dim sum items- they looked at us like they couldn't believe we were ordering off the menu. Good luck getting refill on drinks, getting sauces and asking for napkins. You should just get up and do it yourself.   I would go again, don't have high expectation for service here and you'll be able to enjoy your time here.  Like I said, the food was good.

JX2Q-G1T8K8FMrYlY21DNQ.text: So I'm giving this one a five star because people are sometimes too stingy with the best review possible.  It is True that while this may not be the best dim sum in the world, it is pretty darn good for what you get in Las Vegas.  Quick too, if you want to avoid long waits, this is the spot.  We went during the lunch hour on Sunday (prime time) and were seated in less than 5 minutes.  In less than ten minutes after that, we had food on the table.  Everything came out hot and fresh, and I'm so glad it reopened after having been closed for a while.  Don't buy into negative hype when it comes to the cleanliness of Chinese restaurants because all you're going to do is disappoint yourself.  This is some the best Dim Sum Las Vegas has to offer.

q10QE0-Gj43wnRpS-t8byA.text: We ordered dao miao (pea sprouts) and received something that was definitely not stir fried pea sprouts.   Our rice porridge (congee) was bland and wasn't spectacular.   The entire meal was simply okay. It's great that it's open a little later than other places and you can grab a midnight snack.

4VRUpwlE7kInxmPyFscqDw.text: Good pricing for dim sum. Food was what was expected and wasn't bad but wasn't something I would rave about as well. Over all, would do again for typical dim sum day.

LdBMTOInJ32pGgPVgGGPfA.text: Dim sum here is way better than I expected. Coming from California and Houston, where dim sum is aplenty with very authentic food, I wasn't expecting much from this place.   However, walking in on a weekday (Tuesday) at 11:30am, the place was packed. But more importantly, packed with native Chinese speakers. That's a very very good sign. The authenticity was on point, and the service was very courteous and fast. Carts came around very often, and we got terrific service even though they were packed.   The parking situation in front is troublesome, but after talking to the employees we learned that there was parking in the back. If you're craving dim sum in Las Vegas, this is the place to go!

DVAQdRZLArdftNk7QVUfMA.text: I'm so happy I finally found a place that serves my favorite crispy tofu with shrimp paste with soy sauce on the side. It was so delicious. I ordered it to go and ate it at home. I was happily satisfied with everything. It was kind of hard to order it because they were busy. People were coming in to eat the dim sum. I definitely want to try the dim sum here it looked really good. I like it when they push the carts around.

photos.caption: Photo of Hong Kong Garden Seafood & Dim Sum Cafe - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yummy sooooo good

XBK-fNuUaAySJt65J2krfQ.text: Hands down best dim sum in vegas! We went on a friday morning so there was no wait. I was told that on weekends waits goes out the door! The push cart ladies are super nice. They were a little pushy with the food though. Like they would literally put food on your table when you didnt request for it. They were cool about it if we did decline.  If we wanted something that wasnt in the cart because it was all gone, they made sure that more was on the way. My favorite dim sum dishes was the sui mai, and the garlicky broccoli.  Really every thing was fresh and good. Place is small, I think there was like only 15 tables in the room we were in. I cant imagine going here on a weekend like it be mad busy. Also the parking lot is small. I think I would be stress out looking for a parking spot when eating here. This place hit the spot and definitely my go too place for dim sum when in vegas.

a3tpQXCT2ZMdtwcg1W0-HA.text: Our hiking group comes to Chinatown for dim sum every year around Chinese New Year.  We went yesterday because one of the group will be in Taiwan during the New Year time.  We used to come here when it was the Cathay House and decided to come back.  The member of our group who is going to Taiwan stopped in the week before and reserved the private room for us.  The place has been renovated a bit with the main part of the restaurant now all on one floor.  Opposite the entrance and down a few steps is the private room with its large, round table with lazy Susan for easy sharing.  One problem with the room though is the carts have no way of coming down the steps to the room so you order what you want but you can't see it like we used to as the carts are wheeled around.  A few times one of the women brought a dish to the room to see if we wanted but for the most part, our Asian friend ordered for us.  We got the standard pork shumai, steamed pork buns, sesame balls, and rice noodle rolls.  In addition, there was an order for Singapore noodles and chow fun.  The Singapore noodles were quite good with a good amount of curry.  The food was OK for our lunch.  Service was good but we needed to ask for water which came as we were nearing the end of our meal.  I like the restaurant and it was almost filled.  I'm sure we'll be back another time to enjoy lunch.
